conclusion: Analyze forces acting on oil droplets and use motion information to determine proportionality constant k.
Gravitational force on droplets is F_g = m_0 g.
Air resistance on droplets is f = k m^{1/3} v.
Electric force on droplets is F_e = qE, where E = U/d.
Droplet A falls with uniform velocity v_1, forces in equilibrium: m_0 g = k m_0^{1/3} v_1.
Simplified equation for droplet A: g = k m_0^{-2/3} v_1.
Droplet B rises with uniform velocity v_2 after voltage is applied, forces in equilibrium: m_0 g + k m_0^{1/3} v_2 = q U/d.
Simplified equation for droplet B: g + k m_0^{-2/3} v_2 = q U/(d m_0).
Relate velocities: v_1 = h_1/t and v_2 = h_2/t.
Combine equations: g = k m_0^{-2/3} h_1/t and g + k m_0^{-2/3} h_2/t = q U/(d m_0).
Substitute g = k m_0^{-2/3} h_1/t into equation for B: k m_0^{-2/3} (h_1 + h_2)/t = q U/(d m_0).
Solve for k: k = q U/(d m_0 (h_1 + h_2)/t).
Final expression for k: k = q U t/(d m_0 (h_1 + h_2)).
